articles.headline: Burger King Shifts Policy on Animals
articles.snippet: Animal welfare advocates called the chain’s shift to more humane egg and meat production a “historic advance.”
articles.abstract: Animal welfare advocates called the chain’s shift to more humane egg and meat production a “historic advance.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In what animal welfare advocates are describing as a “historic advance,” Burger King, the world’s second-largest hamburger chain, said yesterday that it would begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that did not confine their animals in cages and crates.

articles.headline: Sweeps in Iraq Cram Two Jails With Detainees
articles.snippet: Hundreds of Iraqis have been crammed into detention centers designed to hold dozens of people, a monitoring group said.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of Iraqis have been crammed into detention centers designed to hold dozens of people, a monitoring group said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Wednesday, March 28 — Hundreds of Iraqis detained in the Baghdad security crackdown have been crammed into two detention centers run by the Defense Ministry that were designed to hold only dozens of people, a government monitoring group said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Chief Writes Off New York
articles.snippet: Frustrated by a battle to open a store in New York City, Wal-Mart’s chief said, “I don’t think it’s worth the effort.”
articles.abstract: Frustrated by a battle to open a store in New York City, Wal-Mart’s chief said, “I don’t think it’s worth the effort.”
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: Teenager Casts Light on a Shadowy Game
articles.snippet: A Texas boy has become a scared-straight spokesman against a choking game after he nearly died playing it.
articles.abstract: A Texas boy has become a scared-straight spokesman against a choking game after he nearly died playing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: GERONIMO, Tex. — Levi Draher, 16, walked to the front of the Navarro High School gym in early March and picked up the microphone before a hushed audience of fellow teenagers.

articles.headline: Break Seen in Logjam Over Trade
articles.snippet: Democrats in the House proposed a series of revisions that won guarded praise from both organized labor and the Bush administration.
articles.abstract: Democrats in the House proposed a series of revisions that won guarded praise from both organized labor and the Bush administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27  Prospects for Congressional approval of several pending trade pacts received a surprising lift on Tuesday when Democrats in the House proposed a series of revisions that won guarded praise from both organized labor and the Bush administration.

articles.headline: Earth’s Climate Needs the Help of Incentives
articles.snippet: Congress seems poised to pass a bill to deal with climate change, but some ideas would do very little to change the situation.
articles.abstract: Congress seems poised to pass a bill to deal with climate change, but some ideas would do very little to change the situation.

articles.headline: Uranium Ignites ‘Gold Rush’ in the West
articles.snippet: Convoluted economics and intense speculation have pushed up the price of uranium to levels not seen since the heyday of the industry in the mid-1970s.
articles.abstract: Convoluted economics and intense speculation have pushed up the price of uranium to levels not seen since the heyday of the industry in the mid-1970s.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA SAL, Utah — Given its connotations, Pandora is an oddly inappropriate name for an uranium mine.
articles.byline: By Susan Moran and Anne Raup

articles.headline: After Congo Vote, Neglect and Scandal Still Reign
articles.snippet: Six months after a historic election, the fledging government is struggling to put Congo back together.
articles.abstract: Six months after a historic election, the fledging government is struggling to put Congo back together.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINDU, Congo — The highway out of town is a single dirt motorcycle track. The colonial-era railroad has finally broken down. The last of the mighty river barges lies rotting on shore with weeds shooting up through its ribs.
